text:
HBS tasks us with
being leaders who

make a positive
difference in the world.

Even if I have big
goals and ambitions,

I hope to make a difference
in the people around me

that I'm lucky to
have in my life.
It takes all of us.

And so I think that
the power to influence

those in your immediate
vicinity, that's exponential.

And that's how the
big things happen.

I grew up in Manhattan Beach,
California, which is in LA.

And I have a younger brother
and a younger sister.

My parents have both been
tremendous influences on me.

And they are amazing in sort
of the fullness of the life
that they have led.

They both spent time
in finance but they're
both very entrepreneurial.
My dad now has his own business.

And my mom, when I
was in high school,

opened a bookstore, which has
been a lifelong dream of hers.
I went to Princeton.

And I studied international
affairs and public policy.

I focused on international
economic policy, which I love.

What I learned from the
interdisciplinary major

is how much I liked
complex problems.

That actually led me to work
at Centerview Partners, which

is a strategic
advisory investment
bank in New York City.
And I was there for five years.

As a banker and reflecting on
my education in public policy,

I came to appreciate the
role that business plays
in kind of global affairs.

I'd hoped to come to HBS to
get a more general management
education.

I was very excited to develop a
more international perspective,

to get a broader set
of business skills

to then go try and be
more on the management

and operational side than on the
client service advisory side.

Given how difficult the last two
years have been for everyone,

I feel tremendously fortunate to
have spent the pandemic at HBS.

I don't think there's anywhere
else I would rather be.

As president of
Section G, I felt

it was important to
be as close to campus

and my Section
mates as possible.
They have meant the world to me.

And so being near them and
having the opportunity to see
them was a huge draw.

The other student leaders
and my classmates,

the impact of those individuals
will certainly be something

from the last two
years that will change

the way that I am not
only professionally,
but just as a person.

Let's give it up for the
gladiators of Section G.

More sort of on
the academic side,

I think coming from a
finance focused background,

it was great to
open the aperture

and learn a little
bit more about how

finance fits into the rest
of business management.

I still kind of love
finance, though.
I'm a big Excel nerd.

So that will certainly
stay with me forever.

I will be moving
to London, again,

part of the plan to be more
internationally minded.

And I'll be working for Bain and
Company doing consulting work.

The past years have been
trying in ways that many of us
never could have anticipated.

And my hope is that this
speech speaks to people

and provides them with
some hope, and excitement,

and inspiration about what lies
ahead because I believe deeply

that if we're on the lookout
for those small things,

and if we are the agents
of those small actions,

they can have a
really big impact.
